title: What are the similarities between Western and Eastern philosophy? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve been thinking a lot about this lately as I once again delve deeply into Eastern philosophy. I think the difference is just like that between the front and back of an elephant. It is a difference in perspective only. Having said this most Eastern philosophy has come about through introspection, while Western philosopher’s focus has always been on the external. So for example the aim of Western philosophy is knowledge while the aim of Eastern philosophy is self-realization. I would contend that they are both the same object from different perspectives as the Greek aphorism γνῶθι σεαυτόν (know thyself) suggests. I clearly remember the warning from one of my early Buddhist teachers that Eastern philosophy is not merely, or even primarily, an intellectual pursuit, but rather always to be grounded in a practice. Having studied both, however, at advanced levels I can tell you one just really has to keep the seeming contradictions in one’s mind. Just like if one was presented with two different pictures of an animal that one has never seen, for example, let’s pretend we don’t know what elephants look like and we have to figure it out from a picture that looks squarely at the front and another one that looks squarely at the rear. Now, I have to add that I am a practicing Catholic, and I believe in the revelation entrusted to the Church. Following Tolkien I would call Christianity the one true (historic) myth. In this sense every other mythology in the world is a partial reflection of Christianity. One problem for us today is that due to its historicity Christianity has so far only been reconciled with Western philosophy. As St. John informs us in his Gospel, Christ is the Logos, and the history of Western philosophy since the Greeks has been primarily formed by the needs of theology up until just a few hundred years ago, when Western philosophy started to break with theology. Now, on the other hand, Eastern philosophy is still largely connected primarily to “spirituality” never really having had any type of theology, culturally. However, Christ isn’t just the Logos, He is also the Tao (and the Dharma, too, for that matter) and as a result our whole understanding of Christianity has been culturally lopsided. Christianity is not a “Western” religion. It is not only the one true historical myth, but it is also the only true world religion, but so far we’ve only been looking at it from one side. That is historically and culturally it has been successfully married to Greek philosophy, the fruit of which was the “Western” culture that followed, but it’s real destiny lies in producing a world culture, which seems to be happening through the Chinese today. When China comes to dominate world culture it will not only offer us, as the British and U.S. have, Empire or neo-Empire, but like Rome it will offer the world a truly new civilization, and when Christian theology is equally developed along the lines of Taoism, Confucianism and Chinese Communism, as it has already been along the lines of Greek philosophy, only then will we really have the true sense of the relationship between the front and the back or the “Eastern” and “Western” perspectives. So for right now, we can’t really imagine what the whole animal (elephant) looks like, again we just have hold the seeming contradictions of the two perspectives in our minds as we study/practice both.

(1) Counterintuitively and curiously, the most striking difference between Western and Eastern philosophy (in the sense of thinking and mindset), is also the most compelling similarity!
